snippet: A cheaper renminbi makes Chinese exports more competitive in overseas markets, but it could worsen trade friction with Europe and particularly the United States.
abstract: China's central bank pushed down the renminbi 0.9 percent in May against the dollar, a steeper drop than in any other month since the government began allowing the currency to appreciate gradually in the summer of 2005; shift could help Chinese exports but worsen trade friction with Europe and particularly the United States.

byline.contributor: Xu Yan contributed research from Shanghai.

lead_paragraph: A cheaper renminbi makes Chinese exports more competitive in overseas markets, but it could worsen trade friction with Europe and particularly the United States.

headline.seo: China Lets Currency Weaken, Risking New Trade Tensions
